In general, rights under a contract involving no personal confidential relation and no exceptional personal skill or knowledge are assignable. An executory contract which is not personal in character and which can, consistent with the rights and interests of the adverse party, be sufficiently executed by the assignee, is assignable, in the absence of an agreement to the contrary.
Special Products Mfg., Inc. v. Douglass, 159 A.D.2d 847, 553 N.Y.S.2d 506 (3d Dep't 1990)
The courts will generally recognize and enforce a provision in a contract expressly prohibiting its assignment.
Sacks v. Neptune Meter Co., 144 Misc. 70, 258 N.Y.S. 254 (App. Term 1932), aff'd, 238 A.D. 82, 263 N.Y.S. 462 (1st Dep't 1933)
32:51. Marketing contract between cooperative and producer for purchase and sale of agricultural products
, a nonprofit cooperative corporation organized under the laws of the State of New York, referred to as
whose principal place of business and address for receiving correspondence regarding this agreement is
[an independent producer/a member of the corporation]
In consideration of the following mutual covenants, Corporation and Producer agree as follows:
Corporation buys from Producer and Producer sells to Corporation all
produced by or for Producer or acquired by Producer as landlord or lessor, which products are
, except products that Producer reserves for personal use and not for sale. Producer agrees to deliver all such products at places directed by Corporation.

Corporation and Producer agree that title to all products subject to this agreement shall pass as soon as they have a potential existence. However, risk of loss shall be borne by Producer until delivery.
Corporation may exercise any powers conferred on it under this agreement through any central agency of which Corporation and any other similar organization are or may become members.
Corporation agrees to make such advances to Producer on products delivered under this agreement as in the discretion of its board of directors may be justified by marketing conditions.
5. MANNER OF DETERMINING PRICE; REVOLVING FUND; POOLS

Corporation agrees to sell, either in the natural or processed state, products delivered by Producer under this agreement, together with the products delivered by other Producers, and to pay over ratably the net amount received therefrom as payment in full to Producer after making deductions:

to cover advances, interest on advances, costs of picking, gathering, harvesting, receiving, assembling, transporting, handling, grading, packing, inspecting, processing, financing, advertising, storing, insuring, selling, and marketing such products and products derived therefrom;
to cover organization, operating, and maintenance expenses;
for capital in a central agency;
to cover a revolving fund retained for the purpose of building up such an amount of capital as may be deemed necessary by its board of directors from time to time; and
as needed for revolving such capital in the manner that may be provided in the Corporation's bylaws.
The aggregate of such deductions shall not exceed
of the gross sales price of such products and products derived therefrom/[number of cents] cents per [bushel/carton/[specification of other unit]]]

Corporation, within the discretion of its board of directors, is authorized to establish, from time to time, daily, weekly, monthly, or seasonal pools of the agricultural products marketed by it of the same variety, grade, and quality. All Producers having such products in a particular pool shall share ratably in the net amount received therefrom.

All products shall be delivered by Producer at the earliest reasonable time after harvesting at such places as Corporation may direct, and with such identification at Producer's expense as may be prescribed by the Corporation.
Any loss that Corporation may suffer on account of inferior or damaged condition of products at delivery shall be charged against Producer.

Producer further agrees that Corporation or central marketing agency, individually or jointly, shall have the power to borrow money for any purpose of Corporation or central marketing agency on the security of the products delivered to Corporation, the products derived therefrom, or on any evidence of such products, byproducts, or cash accounts arising from their sale and to give a lien, either legal or equitable thereon, as the absolute owner. Producer also agrees that Corporation or central marketing agency may grade, pool, or commingle any part of such products or products derived therefrom with other products or products derived therefrom of like grade and variety and shall exercise all other rights of ownership without limitation.
9. LIQUIDATED DAMAGES FOR PRODUCER'S BREACH OF AGREEMENT

Producer and Corporation agree that this agreement is one of a series dependent for its true value on the adherence of each and all of the contracting parties to all such agreements and that the cancellation of this agreement for the failure of Producer to comply with it shall not affect other similar agreements. Producer and Corporation also agree that the remedy at law for any breach of this agreement would be inadequate and that it would be impracticable and extremely difficult to determine the actual damage resulting to Corporation should Producer fail to deliver the covered products, regardless of the cost of such failure.
Producer agrees to pay to Corporation as liquidated damages for all products sold, delivered, or withheld by or for Producer's benefit, other than in accordance with the terms of this agreement,
[$[dollar amount of liquidated damages for all product]/the sum of $[dollar amount of liquidated damages payable] per [specification of unit] on all products]
10. COSTS AND EXPENSES OF LEGAL ACTION

If Corporation files an action by reason of a breach or threatened breach of this agreement, Producer shall pay all court costs, costs for bonds and otherwise, expenses of travel and all expenses arising out of or caused by the litigation, and reasonable attorney's fees expended or incurred by it in such proceedings, and all such costs and expenses shall be included in the judgment.
11. INTEGRATION OF CERTIFICATE AND BYLAWS INTO AGREEMENT
The articles of incorporation and the bylaws of corporation, now or hereafter in effect, and this agreement constitute the entire agreement between Corporation and Producer.
12. OTHER AGREEMENTS; PRODUCER'S APPLICATION FOR CORPORATION MEMBERSHIP

Corporation may enter into agreements with other Producers differing in terms from those contained in this agreement but consistent with the bylaws of Corporation without invalidating this agreement, provided that Producer at Producer's request may sign a similar agreement as a substitute for this agreement. By signing this agreement, Producer, unless already a member, applies for membership in Corporation, and the signing of this agreement by Corporation will constitute an acceptance of such application.

Corporation or the central agency shall establish or adopt standards for products and shall make rules and regulations governing the product's handling and shipping and shall provide inspectors or graders to grade the products. Producer agrees to be bound by such grading and to observe such rules and regulations. Association or the central agency shall provide for the inspection of all products delivered under this agreement and, if any such products are not in proper condition for sale, they shall be prepared for sale at Producer's expense.
After this agreement has been in effect

years from the date of its acceptance by Corporation, either party to the agreement may terminate it in any year on the last day of the anniversary month in which this agreement was so accepted by notifying the other party in writing of this intention, such notice to be given between the

day of the month immediately prior to the effective date of termination. If neither party terminates this agreement in any year, it is mutually agreed that such failure shall constitute conclusive evidence that the parties have renewed this agreement for another year.

If there is a lien on any of the products delivered under this agreement, Producer authorizes Corporation or central agency to pay the holder of such lien from the proceeds derived from the sale of such products before any payment is made to Producer under this agreement.

The parties agree that there are no oral or other conditions, promises, covenants, representations, or inducements in addition to or at variance with any other terms of this agreement and that this agreement represents the voluntary and clear understandings of both parties fully and completely.
A farmer's cooperative must limit the amount of business i

does with nonmembers. It may market products or purchase supplies and equipment for nonmembers only if: (i) the value does not exceed the value of the products, supplies, and equipment of members; and (ii) the value of the purchases made for those who are neither members nor producers does not exceed 15
. In addition, buying and selling for its own profit, such as selling by-products of purchases made for members to nonmembers, will disqualify a cooperative, even if sales are minimal.
This explains the inclusion of a provision like that of Section 12 in the above agreement, which makes the contract itself an application for membership and an acceptance of that application.

The revolving fund method of financing referred to in Section 5 is a hybrid type of security that has elements of both debt and equity. Because of the dual nature of the certificates of interest that are issued in this fund, they have sometimes been declared to be stock and other times indebtedness. See
Mertens Law of Federal Income Taxation
for a more complete discussion of the taxation of cooperatives and their patrons.

In case of fire, boiler explosion, interruption of power, strikes or other labor disturbances, lack of transportation facilities, shortage of labor supplies, perils to the city, floods, earthquakes, action of the elements, invasion, war, riot, insurrection, rebellion, interference of civil or military authorities, enactment of legislation, or any unavoidable casualty or cause beyond the Packer's control, affecting the conduct of Packer's business to the extent of preventing or unreasonably restricting, receiving, handling, processing, or packaging operations, including any obligation on Packer's part to transfer the fruit covered by this agreement or to furnish bins therefor, Packer will be excused for performance under this contract during the period that Packer's business or packaging operations are so affected. Packer may, during such period, accept such portion of the fruit as Packer has informed Corporation in its judgment it can economically handle.

Packer shall immediately give Corporation written notice of Packer's inability to perform and the specific cause or causes thereof. In any event, Packer shall pay, according to contract, for all fruit received by Packer.

With respect to the fruit that Packer has advised Corporation of its inability to handle pursuant to Section 4, Corporation retains the right, without liability of any kind or character to Packer, to divert the fruit to a Packer who is able to accept it in order to prevent economic waste to the growers and consumers.

member of fruit covered by this agreement are so affected that such member or members are unable to make complete delivery of the fruit, Corporation shall make every reasonable effort to complete deliveries under this contract. If Packer shall neglect or fail to meet the reasonable bin requirements of grower

members and Corporation on account of such neglect or failure.

Packer shall not be liable for damages when Packer cannot supply bins because of strikes, fire, acts of God, or other causes beyond Packer's control and of which notice has been given to Corporation under Section 4 of this contract. Packer shall not be liable for damages when Packer has allocated bins on a reasonable basis among grower
members of Corporation and other growers from which Packer purchases fruit.

All fruit delivered under this contract shall be of the quality and grades in effect for such fruit as may be developed and established by Packer or Corporation with approval of the other. In the event Packer establishes various grades by which different prices of grade may be paid grower

members on the basis of grade in accordance with the provisions of Sections 16 through 22.

21. DAMAGES FOR FAILURE TO RECEIVE FRUIT
If Packer, for any reason other than a price dispute, fails, neglects, or refuses, without just legal cause, to receive prior to the

of any crop season covered by this agreement any fruit sold under this contract and that Packer is obligated by this agreement to receive, Packer will pay all reasonable damages caused by such failure unless the receiving date is extended by mutual agreement of grower-members, Packer, and Corporation.
Unless otherwise agreed upon by grower and Packer, payments to grower-members of Corporation who deliver fruit under this agreement will be made by Packer within
days after full delivery and establishment of price and on demand for payment by grower-members.
The division of payments for fruit will be as follows:
of the payments due on delivered fruit shall be paid directly from Packer to grower-members, and
of the payments due on delivered fruit and the entire service charge, as referred to in Section 25 of this contract, shall be paid to Corporation in accordance with the terms of that section.
If Packer, for any reason, fails to pay for the fruit or any other charges that Packer is obligated by this agreement to pay, either to grower
members directly or to Corporation, on the date or dates agreed upon, interest at
per month or any part of the month on the unpaid balance will commence to run immediately on such default.

If Packer shall default or fail in the performance of any of its obligations under this contract, Corporation may stop any further deliveries to Packer and may deliver the balance of fruit elsewhere. This right may be exercised at any time although Corporation has permitted deliveries to Packer to continue after such default or failure. Continuance of delivery after Packer's default or failure in the performance of any of its obligations shall not be construed as a waiver of Corporation's right to stop deliveries. Such delivery of fruit elsewhere shall not be a waiver or release of any liability of Packer for default or failure in performance. Packer may be held liable to Corporation or its grower-members for damages suffered as a result of such default.

If Corporation shall default or fail in the performance of any of its obligations under this contract, Packer may stop any further acceptance of fruit under the contract. This right may be exercised at any time although Packer has accepted delivery from Corporation members after such default or failure in the performance of any of its obligations under this contract. Continuance of delivery after Corporation's default or failure will not be construed as a waiver of Packer's right to stop receiving. Termination of receiving shall not be a waiver or release of any liability of Corporation for default or failure in performance. Corporation may also be held liable to Packer for damages suffered as a result of the default.

Packer recognizes that the organization and continued existence of Corporation relieves Packer of the trouble, labor, and uncertainty of soliciting and obtaining separate contracts with individual growers for the purchase and sale of fruit. In consideration thereof, Packer shall pay to Corporation, over and above the market price designated in this agreement, a service charge of $

per ton for all fruit delivered to Packer under this contract and for all fruit delivered by agency growers who are members of Corporation. The service charge shall not be construed to be a part of the purchase price under this agreement.

If, during the terms of this agreement, Corporation sells to any Packer fruit of its grower-members at a price less than the price specified in Sections 16 through 21, Corporation will pay to Packer, on all fruit purchased under this contract, the difference between the price established in this agreement and the lowest price at which Corporation shall make sales to other packers.

In case any disagreement arises between the parties to this contract, either as to procedures under or interpretations of disagreement, there shall be an arbitration in the manner and under the conditions provided in Section 20.

If Packer, during or for any season under this contract, has purchased or has agreed to purchase any fruit from a grower-member of Corporation, from anyone other than Corporation, or from anyone other than a member of Corporation at a higher price or prices than established in this agreement in accordance with Sections 16 through 21, either upon the basis of grade or without grades, Packer will pay to Corporation for fruit purchased under this contract the highest price that Packer has paid or has agreed to pay or shall have paid or shall have agreed to pay for fruit so purchased from anyone.

In computing the higher purchase price so paid or agreed to be paid, there shall be included any bonuses, premiums, hauling or loading allowances, expenses of special services of any character that may be rendered by Packer or at its expense, and any sums paid or agreed to be paid by Packer for any other designated purpose than payment of purchase price. Nothing contained in this section shall apply to sales of fruit between packers.

Under the New York Uniform Commercial Code, as under prior statutory and case law, the parties, if they so intend, can conclude a contract for sale even though the price is not settled. Where not settled by the agreement, the price to be paid is a reasonable price at the time for delivery, if: (a) nothing is said as to price; (b) the price is left to be agreed by the parties and they fail to agree; or (c) the price is to be fixed in terms of some agreed market or other standard as set or recorded by a third person or agency and it is not so set or recorded.

32:55. Producers' warranty of control of crop

Producer expressly warrants that producer controls the crops subject to this agreement and can deliver according to this agreement and that producer has not, up to this time, contracted to sell, market, or deliver any of such crops to any person, firm, or corporation, except as disclosed in a statement that must appear at the end of this agreement. Any crops to be delivered according to such existing written agreement will be excluded from the terms of this agreement to the extent and for the period of time applicable.
32:56. Corporation's rights upon producer's direct sale to third persons; liquidated damages

Except as provided in subsection (b) of this section, corporation shall, by right of subrogation, have all rights, privileges, and benefits accruing to producer as a result of transactions between producer and any dealer to whom products covered by this agreement are sold. Any person, firm, or corporation receiving such products from producer, after notice, will make payment to corporation of all money due or to become due producer for any such products as may be demanded by corporation. Any person, firm, or corporation continuing to receive such products after notice of the execution of this agreement will be deemed to accept them subject to the terms and conditions of this agreement, and any such products sold or delivered by producer to any person, firm, or corporation, whether in violation of the terms and provisions of this agreement or not, will be sold subject to this agreement.

If producer is offered a direct contract for such products, producer will immediately report such offer in writing to corporation. Corporation may permit members to contract for the sale of products for limited periods directly to dealers distributors or other purchasers designated by corporation, but only on such terms and conditions as are authorized by corporation in writing and provided that corporation is guaranteed full and prompt payment of all deductions authorized by this agreement or by the bylaws and rules of corporation with respect to such direct sales.

In the event of the failure of any dealer or other purchaser mentioned in subsection (a) or (b) of this section to deliver the products or the proceeds from their sale, as set forth above, producer will be obligated to corporation for liquidated damages herein provided on the basis of the amount of products covered directly or indirectly by such transfer, in addition to the other remedies granted in this agreement.

The marketing agreement may fix specific sums as liquidated damages, which sums will not be regarded as penalties, payable for breach by a member or shareholder or contracting nonmember of the marketing obligation. A provision of this type may also be placed in the certificate of incorporation or bylaws.

32:57. Transferee of producer subject to marketing agreement
If the producer transfers any or all of producer's
or any or all of the product owned or controlled by producer to any person, firm, or corporation, on or after the

of any calendar year, any such transfer will be deemed to be subject to this contract during the calendar year in which such transfer is made, providing that this contract has not been terminated in such year, and the transferee will be obligated to deliver the product under this contract.

In the event of the transferee's failure to deliver the product, the producer will be obligated by the corporation for liquidated damages on the basis of the amount of the product covered directly or indirectly by such transfer, in addition to the other remedies granted in this contract.

The certificate of incorporation, bylaws, or the marketing contract may fix specific sums, in amounts fairly related to the actual damages ordinarily suffered in like circumstances, to be paid to the corporation as liquidated damages by a member who fails to perform any obligation to the corporation imposed upon him or her by the certificate of incorporation, the bylaws or a contract between the person and the corporation.

of the total market value of such products. Market value is to be determined as of the time that demand for shipment of the products is made by corporation. If the products have been sold by producer, then the price for which the products have been sold will be their market value.

32:59. Payment and deductions from sale of pooled products; advances

Corporation agrees to resell such products of producer as may be pooled, together with products of like quality, grade, and classification delivered by other growers under substantially similar contracts, at the best prices obtainable under market conditions and to pay over the net amount received therefrom as payment in full to producer and producers named in contracts substantially similar to this agreement, according to the value of the products delivered by each producer after deducting therefrom the cost of receiving, handling, packing, manufacturing, storing, depreciation, advertising, and marketing and an investment charge not to exceed

of the gross resale proceeds. From this charge, a commercial reserve may be created and deductions made for the creation of the capital funds of corporation, provided for by the bylaws thereof. The annual surplus from any deductions made by corporation and not prorated to any specific fund must be prorated among the producers delivering products in that year on the basis of their respective deliveries.

Corporation agrees to pay an advance payment on the products as substantial as the market and financial conditions will permit, as determined by the board of directors in each season. Such payment will be made as soon as practicable after delivery of the products to corporation. Such advance payment may be proportionately higher for products classified in the more desirable grades or sizes from a commercial standpoint.
Payment on each pool will be made from time to time, as rapidly as possible, in due proportion, until the accounts of each pool of the season are completely settled.

seller relationship exists between the cooperative and the patron, advance payments will have to be taken into income when received. Among the many requirements imposed on cooperatives is that of giving notification regarding distributions to the patrons.

. The usual manner of handling this is to incorporate a provision into the bylaws similar to the above and then giving patrons a copy of the bylaw along with the letter of notification described. This must be done before a contract is entered into because, under the Code, the obligation to pay patronage dividends must have existed before the organization received the amount so paid, meaning before the transaction is entered into with the patron.

Notice must be mailed within the period named in this agreement to be effective and will be mailed to corporation at its personal place of business and to producer at producer's last-known address.
32:62. Exercise of corporation's powers through central sales agency
Corporation may exercise all packing, marketing, grading, and inspection or other powers and rights granted in this agreement to it and perform all obligations herein assumed by it, through

as a central sales agency. Producer acknowledges that corporation has or will become a member of such central sales agency and has or will contract with the central sales agency to deliver all of the products handled by it to the central sales agency for packing and marketing. Producer agrees that corporation may contract with the central sales agency for these purposes and may agree to pool the products delivered under this agreement with products of a similar grade and quality delivered by similar corporations under marketing agreements substantially similar to this; the proceeds of this agreement will be divided ratably according to deliveries from such corporations and will be distributed to the grower members as above provided.
32:63. Passage of title to delivered products
Producer agrees that title to products passes absolutely to corporation on their delivery to corporation by producer and that corporation may transfer title to

. Producer agrees that corporation or such central sales agency may hypothecate such products pursuant to borrowing money and incurring indebtedness in the manner and to the extent provided in the agreement between corporation and the central sales agency.

32:64. Agreement binding on members of partnership if partnership terminated
If this agreement is signed by the members of a partnership, it will apply to them and to each of them individually in the event of the partnership's dissolution or termination.
32:65. Corporation to act for all producers in legal proceedings respecting agreement

This agreement is one of a series generally similar in terms comprising, with all such agreements signed by individual producers where otherwise, one single contract between corporation and the producers. Producers, and each of them, agree that corporation will be deemed to be acting in its own name for all producers in any action or legal proceeding on or arising out of this contract.
32:66. Producer's right to inspect books and accounts

All books, accounts, and other documents affecting the business to be carried on by corporation will, at all times during business hours, be open to the inspection of producer or any person designated by the producer who may present proper evidence of authority to make such examination.

A written report, which includes a statement of services rendered by the corporation, a statement of the total amount of business transacted, a balance sheet, an income and expense statement, and other appropriate information is required to be submitted at the annual meeting of the corporation; and such information is required at all times to be available for inspection by any member.

Except as herein otherwise provided, no subsequent alteration, amendment, change, or addition to this Contract will be binding upon the parties hereto unless reduced to writing and signed by the party or parties affected thereby.
